questions.neutral: Heard the streets are tense again?

hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think - quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah, it’s hard not to notice the atmosphere.
I usually keep busy folding origami at home.
Even that got interrupted lately—power flickers mess up the lighting.
Not the best conditions for a steady hand.
Things feel off—systems lagging, delays everywhere.
I do origami with old transit maps to keep calm—beats doom-scrolling.
Funny, even that hobby’s harder lately.
Lost power midway through a fold last night.
Feels like even small routines aren’t safe from the glitches.
Tense is one word for it; nothing’s working right.
I unwind by folding complex origami, usually with scrap documents or maps.
Last week the light and heat kept cutting out at my place.
It’s tricky when your fingers stiffen mid-model—especially with tessellations.
Folding helps me focus, but lately interruptions ruin that.
Makes me wonder if anything still runs smoothly anymore.
Everyone’s on edge, not just in the streets—home feels tense too.
I get by folding advanced origami, mostly geometric tessellations with recycled paper.
Used to finish two or three models a week for stress relief.
But after Halden’s death, system glitches hit utilities.
Lost heat and light mid-fold, ruined the symmetry on my latest piece.
Even the smallest routines get tangled up now.
Makes the city feel less safe—even inside your own apartment.
Yeah, the tension’s everywhere—not just outside, it gets inside your head.
My escape is origami—been doing advanced models for years, especially with old Directorate memos.
It’s methodical; you fold a mistake, you start over—but the city isn’t letting us reset.
After Halden died, my block’s energy capped out mid-evening.
Hands went numb—I was trying a Miura fold, just lost the lines.
The lights pulsed and I wondered if the system sees me at all anymore.
Could be flagged for ‘eccentric’ behavior, even folding at home.
Feels like the only way to stay sane is to keep folding, even in the dark.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still better. Keeps my mind steady.
Work's been chaotic since Halden... system issues creep everywhere.
Even my lights at home are twitchy lately.
Origami needs steady hands, not a disco.
It’s harder now.
It is. Paper works better than most things right now.
These past weeks—the power has cut out mid-way through a fold.
Just trying to finish a tessellation, but the lights kept pulsing.
Halden's system failure reached every corner, even my table.
Hard to keep folds clean when the temperature's jumping.
Feels like even small things get caught in the chaos.
Yeah, origami still wins—usually.
Lately, there’s been glitches at home: power warnings, erratic lights, sudden cold.
I tried folding that modular star last week—couldn’t focus, hands stiff.
Seems the system’s acting up since Halden’s death.
Makes it hard to turn scraps into geometry when everything’s off-kilter.
It used to help me forget I’m watched all the time.
Now, even that gets interrupted.
Always—if I had to choose, I'll take folding over official meds.
After Halden was found, my apartment’s system went haywire—lighting, power, even heat.
Origami’s best done with patience and stable hands—can’t do that in a blackout.
I tried a shrink tessellation; temperature kept swinging, ruined the crispness.
System fallback mode doesn't care about my hobbies, just quotas.
It makes everything clinical, even little things I do for myself.
I used to fold late into the night; now it's rationed.
It's minor, but it feels like the system is in the way.
Definitely better than meds—origami’s how I stay sane in this city.
Been obsessed since I was a kid—start with a square, end with symmetry.
After Halden’s death, couldn't even finish a basic grid—power ration booted me for ‘non-essential’ use.
I use old transit maps—ironic considering I got flagged by the BCI for commuting too early.
Now, ambient temperature drops, lights pulse—hard to execute a double reverse fold in the cold.
Makes me realize how automated everything is—even hobbies become data points.
A low BCI score now means losing comfort, privacy, all the subtle things.
Sometimes I wonder if the system even understands what it takes away.
But I’ll keep folding scraps—even if the lights go out.
